The Buddha said to Nanda:
Why does a mother not receive the womb?

Then the parents give rise to defiled thoughts, and the conditions come together. If the mother has a good and wholesome mind, the spirit of existence comes before her. If the mother loses essence, or if the father loses it and the mother does not, or if the father is pure and the mother is not clean, or if the mother is clean and the father is not clean, or if the mother's womb is complete at that time, then it does not receive the embryo.
In this way, it is complete, or there is cold, or at times the sound is near, and the essence is extinguished, or it is full, or like medicine, or like a fruit in the middle.

Or like a seed in a bitter plant, or like a raw fruit seed, or like a bird's eye, or like a sandpiper's eye, or like a she-wolf's eye, or like a peacock's eye, or like a pupil, or like a tree leaf, or like a lump of dirt.

Then, either deep or shallow, deep or shallow, without a womb, near sound, hard as a pearl, eaten by worms, near left or right, large and clear, sudden and violent, or not well-balanced, turning left to right, like a water bottle, like a fruit seed, like a wolf's penis, with many flaws, all cold together, with much heat, or the parents' work makes the spirit lowly, or the coming spirit is noble and the parents are lowly, therefore they do not pass each other to be born;
equal practice, equal will, both noble and both lowly, the same mind, not different, then enter the mother's womb.
Why does the mother not accept the womb?

Without the above various confused matters and unbalanced matters, with equal intentions, practicing together, both noble and both lowly, due to karmic causes from past lives, a child should be born, and the coming spirit should encounter the parents and become their child.
At that time, the spirit may have two thoughts in mind, each different, and in this case, it will not be able to enter the womb.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
How does one enter the mother's womb?
Those with little blessings will think to themselves:

'There is cold wind and rain from the sky now, and a large crowd is coming to beat and harm me. I should run and hide under a large pile of grass, or enter a pile of leaves and various grasses, or enter a deep valley by a stream, or climb a high cliff, so that no one can reach me and I can escape the cold wind, heavy rain, and the large crowd.'
Then, they enter a house.
Those with abundant blessings and power think to themselves:
'Now there is cold wind, heavy rain, and a large crowd. I should enter a house, or go up to a large lecture hall, or ascend to a flat pavilion and climb onto a bed.'
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
When the spirit enters the mother's womb, the thoughts it has are various and not the same.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

When the spirit enters the womb, it then forms the embryo. As for the formation of the embryo, it is not apart from the parents' impure essence, and it also relies on the parents' impurity. Through the convergence of causes and conditions, it receives the womb. Therefore, it is neither from the parents nor apart from the parents.
For example, Ä€nanda!

Like a vessel filled with curds, if milk is added to it, the causes and conditions will produce curds. If it remains alone, it will not become curds. Curds are not produced from curds, nor are they apart from curds. Only through the convergence of causes and conditions can curds be obtained.
In this way, Ä€nanda!
The body is not formed from the parents' impurity, nor is it formed apart from the parents. It is through the parents as conditions that the womb is formed.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

It is like grass and vegetables giving rise to insects, the insects do not come from the grass and vegetables, nor are they apart from the grass and vegetables, relying on the grass and vegetables as a cause and condition, the insects are born in union, and the insects naturally appear in this way.
It is like this, Ä€nanda!
It is not that the body is formed from the impure substances of the parents, nor is it apart from the impure substances of the parents, but it is formed through the parents as a condition.
It is like, Ä€nanda!

The insects come from wheat, the insects do not come from the wheat nor are they apart from the wheat, but they are born through the wheat as a condition, and the insects are naturally born in union with this.
It is like this, Ä€nanda!

It is not that the body is formed from the impure substances of the parents, nor is it apart from the impure substances of the parents, but it is formed through the parents as a condition, and the various faculties and the four elements are established.
It is like, Ä€nanda!
The worms are not born from the jujube fruit, nor are they born apart from the jujube fruit. They are born naturally, with the jujube fruit as a condition.
In the same way, Ä€nanda,

the body is not born from the parents' impurities, nor is it born apart from the parents' impurities. It is formed in the womb, with the parents as a condition, and the various faculties and the four elements are established.
It is like, Ä€nanda,
the worms born from yogurt. The worms are not born from the yogurt, nor are they born apart from the yogurt. They are born naturally, with the yogurt as a condition.
In the same way, Ä€nanda,

the body is not born from the parents' impurities, nor is it born apart from the parents' impurities. It is formed in the womb, with the parents as a condition, and the various faculties and the four elements are established.

With the parents as a condition, the earth element is established, which refers to all that is solid. The wet and moist water element, the hot and warm fire element, and the breath and energy wind element.
Suppose, Ä€nanda,
Because of the parents, the embryo is formed. The earth element becomes the embryo, and the water element causes it to rot, like dough or skin, which rots when it meets water.
If the embryo were formed by the parents, it would be the water element, not the earth element, because it is thin like moisture, like oil or water.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!ğŸ”½The water element relies on the earth element and does not rot;
the earth element relies on the water element and does not stick.
If, Ä€nanda!
The parents' conditions form the embryo, the earth element becomes the water element, and the fire element cannot rely on it, then it will rot and decay.
For example, in the fifth month of summer, during the height of the hot season, the flesh relies on the fire element, and dust, dirt, and foul odors rot and decay, becoming putrid.
In this way, Ä€nanda!
If the parents' womb forms the earth element and the water element, then the fire element does not rot, decay, or disappear.
Suppose, Ä€nanda!

If the elements of earth and water in the womb were formed from the parents, then there would be the element of fire but not the element of wind. Without the establishment of the wind element, it would not grow and develop, and thus not be accomplished.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!

The spirit dwelling within, due to its merits and demerits, forms the four great elements, which are ultimately grasped by the earth, water, fire, and wind elements. The water element distinguishes, the fire element causes the name, and the wind element then grows and develops, and thus is accomplished.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
It is like a lotus growing in a pond, pure and complete, with the flower buds unopened. Blown by the wind, the flowers open and grow, and thus are accomplished.
In this way, Ä€nanda!

The spirit dwelling within, due to its merits and demerits, forms the four great elements, accomplishes the earth element, grasps the water element, distinguishes the fire element, causes the name of the wind element, and thus grows and develops.
It is gradually accomplished, not due to the conditions of parents' womb, but by the surpassing birth of humans and spirits.
It is not the blessings of parents, nor is it the body of the father or the body of the mother, but by the combination of causes and conditions.

It is not due to empty conditions, nor is it due to various conditions, nor is it due to other conditions. There is also the simultaneous bestowal of the same aspiration, and by combining, the embryo and womb are formed.
An analogy, Ananda!
Like the seeds of the five grains and grasses and trees are complete, not rotten, not worm-eaten, the ground is plowed and covered, the fertile soil sows the seeds, and they grow well.
What do you think, Ananda?
Does the seed stand alone, and by the power of earth and water, does it form its roots, stems, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits?
Ananda said to the Buddha:
No, Heavenly among Heav-ens!
The Buddha said:
So it is, Ananda!
It is not that from the parents' mixed essence, the embryo is formed in the womb. It is not just the parents' remains, nor is it from empty conditions.
There are causes and conditions that come together to form the four great elements and other causes and conditions that appear, such as the Buddha's womb and embryo.
Ananda, it is like

a person with clear eyes holding a maá¹‡i jewel and a sun-concentrating lens facing the sun at noon, and then using dry cow dung, mugwort, or cloth, immediately fire will emerge and become a blazing flame.
Consider that fire, it does not come from the sun, the maá¹‡i jewel, the sun-concentrating lens, or the mugwort, nor does it exist apart from them.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!
When causes and conditions come together and are present, fire can be produced without increase or decrease.

The embryo is like this, not from the parents, not apart from the parents, and also due to the impure essence of the parents, it forms the womb and thus forms form, sensation, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, and thus receives a name, and thus receives a designation, and due to the original formation of form, it is called name-and-form.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!
I do not praise the going and coming to the end of arising from conditions.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
It is like a few sores and foul-smelling places that are not enjoyed by non-humans, let alone many?
How much more so for many holes and faults?
In this way, Ä€nanda!
I do not praise the few cycles in the end and beginning, let alone a long time.
Why is it so?
All the suffering of ending and transmigrating is very difficult, who would enjoy it? How could one delight in a foul-smelling place and enter a mother's womb?
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
It has been seven times since he first received a mother's womb.
How does it naturally become a fetus?
When first lying down and not yet accomplished, the fetus is naturally also like this.

For seven days, it remains there without increasing or decreasing. As it gradually heats up and becomes more solid, the earth element is established. The soft and wet part becomes the water element, the warmth in it becomes the fire element, and the space in between becomes the wind element.

On the second seven days, there is a wind called turning that slowly arises and blows it to the left or right side, gathering it into a sac, like the fat on the surface of yogurt. As the essence becomes more solid, it is also like this. For seven days, it gradually transforms like ripe [fruit]. The solid part becomes the earth element, the soft and wet part becomes the water element, the warmth in it becomes the fire element, and the space in between becomes the wind element.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
On the third seven days, in the mother's womb, there is a wind in the womb called 'sound gate' that arises and blows, causing the sac to become more solid.
What does it resemble when it becomes solid?
Just as a finger touches a sore, the sore flesh decays, and the essence transforms in the same way.

For seven days in the womb, it transforms and matures. The solid part becomes the earth element, the soft and wet part becomes the water element, the warm and hot part becomes the fire element, and the space in between becomes the wind element.
The Buddha told Ananda:
In the fourth week, a wind called food arises in the mother's womb, blowing on the fetus and causing it to become solid.
What is its solidity like?
It is like the offspring of blood-sucking creatures, called 'not leaking' in Chinese, and its solidity is like that of the inner bones without trust.

For seven days there, it transforms and matures. The solid part becomes the earth element, the soft and wet part becomes the water element, the warm and hot part becomes the fire element, and the space in between becomes the wind element.
The Buddha told Ananda:

In the fifth week, in the mother's womb, there is a wind called guiding. It blows on the hardened essence and transforms it into the body's five places, the two kneecaps, two shoulders, and one head. It is like in spring when the heavens rain, the rain falls from the sky and nourishes the leaves and branches of trees. The fetus is like this.
In the mother's womb, it transforms into five places, the two kneecaps, two shoulders, and its head.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the sixth week, the fetus inside the mother's womb naturally has a wind called water. It blows on the fetus' body and causes it to transform and form four places, the two knees and two elbows.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the seventh week, in the womb of the mother's abdomen, a natural transformative wind named 'revolving' blows, causing it to change and form four auspicious signs: two hands, two arms, gradually growing longer, soft and weak.
Like when foam dries up, the four signs in the embryo are like this, with the places of the hands and feet appearing.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the eighth week, in the womb of the mother's abdomen, a natural transformative wind named 'retreating' blows, causing twenty signs to appear in the embryo, the places of the ten toes and the ten fingers.
Like when rain falls from the sky, flowing and pouring on the branches, causing them to grow lush, at that time, in the womb, twenty muscles arise, the places of the ten toes and the ten fingers.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the ninth week, in the womb inside the mother's belly, a natural wind arises that blows and transforms the nine orifices: the two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, the mouth, and the two lower orifices.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the seventeenth day, in the womb inside the mother's belly, a natural wind arises called 'pimple-short', which blows on the fetus, causing sudden and severe illness.
For seven days, for seven nights, a natural wind arises called 'universal gate', which arranges the body, just like a strong and complete sound.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the eleventh week, in the womb inside the mother's belly, a natural transformative wind arises called 'arranging destruction', which blows on the fetus and arranges its form, stabilizing the scattered parts, causing the mother to run and be uneasy, agitated and restless, moving slowly with laughter, liking to talk, play, laugh, sing and dance, and wind arises and tears flow out.
In this way, as the fetus sits in the mother's womb, it likes to stretch its hands and feet.

As the fetus turns, the scattered and combined parts are established. There is a wind called pillar-turning, which goes to the top of the head and scatters on the top of the head, causing it to turn upside down, like a blacksmith blowing on an bellows from above.
In this way, Ä€nanda!

That pillar-turning wind goes up to the neck, scatters on the neck, and turns back again. The wind revolves on the neck, opening the throat, mouth, and navel of the body, and the various channels and orifices are made to penetrate and leak, causing it to gradually develop and become complete.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the twelfth week, in the mother's womb, a natural transformative wind called skin-face blows on the fetus, causing the intestines and stomach to form on the left and right sides, like the roots of a lotus flower touching the ground. The intestines are formed and depend on the body in the same way, becoming the eighteen empty channels and orifices.

In seven days, there is a natural transformation wind called casting off hair. It blows and generates its tongue and opens its eyes. It makes the hundred joints of the body complete and perfect, without deficiency or reliance, generating ten thousand and one hundred joints.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the thirteenth week, in the mother's womb, the fetus feels its body weak and also feels hungry and thirsty. The mother's food and drink enter the child's body. The child in the womb, by the mother's food and drink, greatly nourishes the body.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the fourteenth week, in the mother's womb, the fetus naturally has a wind called 'warp and weft gate.' It blows on the essence and generates ninety thousand sinews, twenty-two thousand five hundred in the front of the body, twenty-two thousand five hundred in the back, twenty-two thousand five hundred on the left side, and twenty-two thousand five hundred on the right side.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the fifteenth week, in the mother's womb, a natural transformative wind arises, called 'red lotus flower,' also called 'padma.' It blows on the child's body, causing twenty channels to be arranged. Five channels lead to the front of the body, five channels lead to the back, five channels lead to the left side, and five channels lead to the right side. Within these channels, there are countless and innumerable various colors, each with a name appearing before the eyes.
Next, it is called 'power,' also called 'abiding,' also called 'firm.'

Another type of color, some are blue, some are white, white becomes red, red becomes white, some white becomes yellow, some are light blue, the color of ghee, the color of yogurt and oil, raw heat mixed, ripe heat mixed.

Each of the twenty channels has forty branches, making eight hundred channels. Two hundred are in the front of the body, two hundred are in the back, two hundred are on the left, and two hundred are on the right. Two hundred are in the two powers, two are in the two honored ones, and two are in the two powerful ones.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
Each of the eight hundred channels has ten thousand branches, making eighty thousand channels.
Twenty thousand are in the chest and abdomen, twenty thousand are in the back, twenty thousand are on the left, and twenty thousand are on the right.
The eighty thousand channels have countless empty spaces that cannot be measured.
There is one empty space, then two, then three, up to seven.
It is like a lotus stalk with many holes, with one hole, two holes, three holes, up to seven holes, growing in sequence.
In this way, Ä€nanda!
The eighty thousand channels are also like this, with countless root spaces that cannot be measured, with one, then two, then three, up to seven.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
All the channels and pores rely on each other.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

On the sixteenth week, in the mother's womb, a natural transformative wind called 'immeasurable' blows on the child's body, straightening its bones and joints, opening both eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, and neck, and all around the heart, causing the food and drink to flow unobstructed, and wherever it is established, the pores flow out and in, going against and with the body, causing no mistakes. Even if it is complete, there is no obstruction.
It is like a potter or his disciple mixing the clay well, making the unfired clay form, beating it to make it straight, repairing the top and bottom to prevent leaks, and placing it in its place.
Thus, Ä€nanda!

Due to the causes and conditions of good and evil, a natural wind transforms its physical form, opening its eyes, ears, nose, mouth, throat, and neck, opening its heart, allowing food and drink to pass through, and unobstructedly nourishing its food and drink through all the orifices.
The Buddha told Ananda:

On the seventeenth week, in the womb inside the mother's abdomen, there is a natural wind called Ox-face Consumption, which blows on the child's body, opening its eyes, making them clean and bright, as well as the two ears, nose, and mouth, all making them clean and bright without blemish.
An analogy, Ananda!
Like a mirror polisher or his disciple, taking an unclean mirror, scraping, polishing, and rubbing it, applying oil to make it shine, removing its flaws, and making it transparent inside and out.
In this way, Ananda!
The causes and conditions of sin and merit naturally cause the wind to open their eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, making them pure, clear, and flawless.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the eighteenth week, in the mother's womb, it removes various flaws and makes them all pure.

It is like the moon's palace or a person's palace. There is a wind called 'great strength.' That wind is extremely strong, blowing around the palace and holding it up, naturally pure and ultimately flawless.
The fetus is like this. In the mother's womb, the essence of the senses is blown by the wind, naturally becoming clear and ultimately complete.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

translated: In the nineteenth week, in the womb, it obtains four faculties: the eye faculty, the ear faculty, the nose faculty, and the tongue faculty. Initially in the mother's womb, it obtains three faculties: the body faculty, the mind faculty, and the life faculty.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

On the twenty-seventh day, in the mother's womb, a natural transformative wind named 'Sharp' blows on the child's body, causing bones to form in its left foot, and blowing on the right foot to form bones. There are four bones at the knees, two bones in the kneecaps, eighteen bones in the back, eighteen bones in the sides, thirteen bones in the palms, each with twenty bones in the left and right feet.

There are four bones at the hip joints, two bones in the non-hip joints, two bones in the shoulders, eighteen bones in the neck, three bones in the ear wheels, thirty-two bones in the mouth teeth, and four bones in the head.
It is like this, Ä€nanda!

A carpenter or painter creates a wooden person, first shaping the wooden parts, assembling them securely, stringing the joints with ropes, and using ropes to connect them, thus forming an image no different from a human.
In this way, Ä€nanda!
The transformation of sin and merit naturally gives rise to wind that forms the appearance, transforming into bones and joints, created through causes and conditions.
Within these twenty-seven days, the body in the womb will at that time produce two hundred subtle bones mixed with flesh.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the twenty-first week, in the mother's womb, there is a natural transformative wind called 'existence,' which blows on the child's body, causing flesh and skin to appear.
For example, Ä€nanda!
A skilled potter makes wonderful pottery vessels, jars, pots, and basins, causing them to be fully formed.
Ä€nanda!
The 'existence' wind blows on the child's body, causing flesh and skin to grow, in the same way.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the twenty-second week, in the mother's womb, there is a natural wind called 'crossing evil,' which blows on the child's body, causing sound to arise.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the twenty-third week, in the mother's womb, there is naturally a wind called 'needle-hole purity.' It blows on the child's body, causing the skin to gradually become complete.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the twenty-fourth week, in the mother's womb, there is naturally a wind called 'firm holding.' It blows on the child's body, stretching out the skin and making it even.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the twenty-fifth week, in the mother's womb, there is naturally a transformative wind called 'holding what is heard.' It blows on the child's body, sweeping away the flesh and making it smooth and lustrous.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the twenty-sixth week, in the mother's womb, there is naturally a transformative wind that blows on the child's body. If in a previous life there were evil and sinful actions, the calamities will manifest in the
The ten evil deeds, or being stingy and greedy for wealth and property, unable to give in charity, not accepting the words of the wise,ğŸ”½

Those who commit the ten evil acts, or are stingy and greedy with their wealth and cannot give it away, do not accept the teachings of the sages and teachers, those who should be pure and tall become shorter, those who should be
tall become more slender, those who should be pure and tall become more coarse, those who should have much purity instead

obtain little, those who should have little instead become many, those who should be clean instead become defiled, those who should be defiled instead become clean, those who should be male instead become non-male, those who do not like males instead become male thieves, those who seek instead do not obtain it, those who do not wish for it instead naturally arrive, those who should be black instead become yellow, those who should be yellow instead become
black.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

As one sows evil seeds in one's past lives, one naturally reaps them. One may become blind, deaf, mute, or foolish, with bodily scars, born without eyes, unable to speak, with blocked senses, lame, or crippled. One naturally receives the consequences of one's own past actions, and is despised by one's parents, going against the principles of the Dharma.
Why is it so?
Thus, Ä€nanda!
The non-dharmic actions sown in past lives.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

If a person in a past life practiced many virtues, did not commit any evils, and all wholesome things came to them, namely the ten virtuous actions, they enjoyed giving without a stingy or defiled mind, and upheld the instructions of their past sages and teachers. The joints of their body should be long, and they would be naturally long,
they should be fresh and clean, and naturally fresh and clean, they should be coarse and pure, and coarse and pure, they should be fine and pure, and fine and pure.
If small, it should be many and subtle, if much pure, it should be much pure, if little pure, it should be
little pure, if smooth and fresh, it should be smooth and fresh, if it should be endured little, it should be endured
little, if it should be made strong, it should be made strong, if one desires a good voice, one should obtain a good voice,
if one desires a jeweled necklace, one should obtain a jeweled necklace, if it should be made black, it should be made black, if one desires
speech, one should obtain what one desires.
Thus, Ä€nanda!
In accordance with the merit planted in past lives, all that is good naturally arises, and one is joyfully seen by sentient beings, with the foremost appearance of upright and beautiful purity.
Whatever is sought, done, or wished for by body, speech, and mind, one will obtain as one wishes.
Why is it so?
Therefore, Ä€nanda!
One naturally obtains what was planted in past lives. The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

If it is a boy, it will go to the right side of the mother's abdomen, sit cross-legged, place its two palms on its face, back to the outside, face towards the mother, below the liver and above the intestines, bound by five bonds as if in a leather bag.

If it is a girl, it will sit cross-legged on the left side of the mother's abdomen, with its palms pressed against its face, below the liver and above the intestines, bound by five bonds as if in a leather bag.
If the mother eats too much, the child will be uncomfortable;ğŸ”½if she eats too little, the child will be uncomfortable.
If she eats too much grease, the child will be uncomfortable;
if she eats no grease, the child will be uncomfortable.

If it is too hot or too cold, if she wants to have a bowel movement or not, if it is sweet or sour or coarse or fine, if she eats like this, or if she eats too much or too little and it is not balanced, the child will be uncomfortable.
If the mother's sexual desires are excessive, the child will be uncomfortable;
if she is in the wind and it is excessive, the child will be uncomfortable.
Or if they walk or run a lot, cross over something, or climb a tree, the child is not comfortable.
The Buddha told Ananda:
The child in the mother's womb suffers hardships, troubles, and difficulties, just like this.
Lay people consider themselves born in a comfortable place.
If it is like this, how much more so the hardships and troubles of the evil realms?
The sufferings and difficulties are beyond analogy. Who would enjoy being in the mother's womb?
The Buddha told Ananda:
On the twenty-eighth day,
the child in the womb has eight thoughts:

the thought of riding, the thought of gardens, the thought of pavilions, the thought of outings, the thought of beds, the thought of flowing rivers, the thought of springs, and the thought of bathing pools.
The Buddha told Ananda:

In the twenty-ninth week, in the mother's womb, there is a natural wind called marrow-middle. It holds the skin and makes it clean. The complexion naturally follows one's past actions. If one has done black deeds in the past, the color will appear black, and the body will be like lacquer.ğŸ”½If one has done neither white nor black deeds in the past, the color will appear neither white nor black, and the body will be of one appearance.
If one's past actions have no luster, the color will appear to have no luster, and the whole body will be the same.
If one's past actions are white, the face will be fair, and the whole body will be the same.
If one's past actions are yellow, the face will be yellow, and the whole body will be the same.
Ä€nanda!
These worldly people have these six colors, which they naturally obtain according to what they have sown in the past.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

On the thirty-seventh day, in the mother's womb, a natural wind arises, blowing on the child's body, causing hair and body hair to grow. According to past actions, it may cause the child's hair to be jet black and wonderfully fine, or it may cause the hair to grow yellow, which people dislike.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
On the thirty-first seven-day period, in the mother's womb, the child's body grows larger and becomes complete.
On the thirty-second seven-day period, in the mother's womb, the child's body is fully formed and lacks nothing.

On the thirty-third seven-day period, the thirty-fourth seven-day period, the thirty-fifth seven-day period, and the thirty-sixth seven-day period, the child's body is fully developed and the bones and joints are firm, and he is not happy in the womb.
